reviews.nose: Quite volatile. Also ripe fruit, peaches, and ripe apples. A noticeable influence of fortified wine casks, closest to sherry. A bit of yeast. A blend of sweet and dry. Slightly more complex than Aberfeldy 12 Year Old.
reviews.taste: Sweet, very sweet. Fruity. A mix of ripe fruit, but also slightly fresher ones. Peaches and baked apples again, now with a hint of smoky apples. Sweetness of honey, caramel, and toffee. Definitely fuller than Aberfeldy 12 Year Old. Cinnamon.
reviews.finish: Quite sweet, again ripe fruit, some burnt caramel, and honey. A slight oak bitterness in the background, but much less so than in the Aberfeldy 12 Year Old. No roast. Very smooth and pleasant. Cinnamon.

reviews.content: Classic (or generic, depending on your predisposition) soft Speyside nose, fruity and sweet. Initially it‘s all apple juice and crumbly pies, but soon additional aromas appear, hinting at the stated age of 16 years: musty wood, spices, some leather and varnish. There’s even a „dusty“ element I normally associate with Irish pot still whiskies or older Glen Morays. A pleasant and, to use an overused term, quite an elegant nose. Of course it‘s all rather soft, given the weak ABV. In the mouth, it‘s a bit thin/watery, and due to the low bottling strength, the liquid doesn’t manage to match the diversity and depth of aromas that were promised on the nose. There‘s some sweetness and some juicy acidity, followed by soft spice and restrained bitterness. It‘s all pretty indistinct, though, and over in a heartbeat. The short finish provides fennel and dill notes (from the wood) on a bed of juicy apple and honey (from the distillate). A very tame and restrained malt that is hamstrung (if not outright strangled) by the low ABV. Though refill-heavy, this could really have been something (perhaps on par with the very good, and equally refill-y Glenfarclas 12) if bottled at a higher strength.
Delicious fresh fruit notes (apple) combined with honey. Exceptional citrus notes at 1 in 4 drams.71-80 – Fine, like to drink by time

reviews.nose: Mildly sulphuric malt. Apple juice. Banana mash drizzled with honey. Sultana cookies with melted toffee. Cloves. Fresh Brazil nuts. A whiff of garden mint & summer flowers. Cold copper. A fat nose and a step away from syrupy.
reviews.taste: Oily Sherry. Dried apricots, sultana, figs. Toffee. Spicy oak. A touch of bitter malt. Compared to the nose, it’s watery and thin.
reviews.finish: Short, slightly dry finish. Nutty oak and dried yellow fruits. Fruit skin waxes.

reviews.content: A step up from the 12 years old, it's got a bit more development and some sherried richness. The 40% does is no favour however.
reviews.nose: A malty and sweet start with caramel, vanilla cake, red apples and mandarins. A floral note and some cloves can be distinguished on the background.
reviews.taste: Fruits at the front now, with oranges, apricots and raisins. Honey adds more sweetness to the palate. A nice dark spiciness develops, morphing into black tea and just a hint of smoke. A nice profile, although it's just too fragile and thin to really impress. Another downside is the cardboardy note that develops on the background.
reviews.finish: Apples, citrus fruits and a nice impression of vanilla cake. Some coffee and a spiciness develops, although it becomes quite bitter and tannic after a while. Lingers with a very subtle hint of smoke.

reviews.content: Not everything from the past is better....I paid €70,- for this and that should be way less. Nevertheless a good and easy drinking malt which will please the average malt drinker and makes the blend drinker drink malt forever.

reviews.content: The initial citrus note disappears quite fast. Like the 12er again very malty and grainy, somewhat floral and fresh and therefore more interesting. In the background one suspects sherry influence. In the mouth unfortunately similar unspectacular as the 12-year-old. Quite creamy and pleasant on the tongue with oak, vanilla and honey. Hints of orange and a little peppery. The finish is subtly bitter, a little chocolaty and slightly peppery. Not a malt that sticks in your memory and not a malt you have to have in your bar room at home. But clearly rounder than the 12 year old and good drinkable. 80 points

Again, a lighter and rather mild dram. Quite interesting and yet very different than the old 12er. I honestly did not expect that. Sure, the orange or lemon and the honey characterize the Brennereicharakter, but then there are significant differences. It reminds me a bit of the Timorious Beastie, which is clearly better integrated here.
reviews.nose: Honey, a little bit of grain, very little alcohol to feel, almost no sulfur (only very little), a small tickling in the nose makes the whisky so how should I say something sparkling. And orange.
reviews.taste: Orange and sweet. These are the dominant impressions. And a liveliness. So it seemed to me that I had drunk a whisky with carbonic acid. It was a strange feeling somehow. Not unpleasant but somehow getting used to.
reviews.finish: Scary fast away. So the old 12er stayed longer. The mouth is still a bit busy, but otherwise. There are impressions of honey, toffee and orange. Low seasoning. I can not recognize the long and spicy tendency promised to him.

A very decent dram with a reasonable price. They managed to achieve balance, but just give it enough kick to make it interesting enough to keep sipping.
reviews.nose: Quite spicy at first. Clearly ginger. Then all kinds of yellow fruits that just have not fully ripened. Oranges, nectarines, tangerines, and some of those yellow cherries. This is followed by an upcoming sweetness to balance the spices. Butter, butterscotch and cream cheese. I think this is quite good with proper balance, but not without an edge to keep it interesting. More cookies, cake and other pastries follow, together with apricot filling, almonds and lemon icing. Very nice.
reviews.taste: Compared to the nose, the palate is underwhelming. However when given some time it becomes more vivid with candied orange, ginger, bitter almonds, lemon skin, and grapefruit. The strength feels above the 40% and the bourbon cask does more of the talking compared to the sherry cask. Cinnamon buns, lemon curd, a hint of chocolate and raisins are also there. Everything stays friendly and calm, I mean do not expect too much thrills.
reviews.finish: Reasonably long with hay, pastry, ginger and citrus fruits.

reviews.nose: Intense sherry right at the front and the casks were not cheap. Raisins and dates but also cooked pears. Then there are sweetness from forest honey, ginger and a floral note. This is followed by a hint of oak. Not enough for 16 years and this is mainly due to the low abv.
reviews.taste: Honey sweetness at first, then increasingly spicy. Pears cooked in fruit punch. There is more oak and less sherry now.
reviews.finish: Sweet at first, then finally the amount of oak that should be present in a 16-year-old whisky. Again spices, mainly ginger, and sherry. Additionally, there is milk chocolate.

In general, a good, understandable, no sharp corners molt, corresponding to its stated age.
